The Year RWA Tokenization Went Mainstream

Billions flowed on-chain
Institutional giants flooded in.
Regulations cleared the path.

This is just the beginning  2026 will be multiples bigger. 
RWA didn‚Äôt ‚Äútrend‚Äù in 2025.
It scaled üìà

On-chain real-world assets (ex-stablecoins) grew in '25 from ~$6B ‚Üí $30B+ in a single year.

No hype cycle.
No memecoin froth.
Just capital quietly moving on-chain. 
Where did the money actually go? üëÄ

RWA market breakdown (2025):
‚Ä¢ Private credit: ~60%
‚Ä¢ Tokenised Treasuries: ~30%
‚Ä¢ Real estate, commodities, others: early but accelerating

Credit led the way.
Yield pulled institutions in.
Before RWAs scaled‚Ä¶ stablecoins did.

Stablecoins weren‚Äôt the story in 2025.
They were the infrastructure everything else rode on. 
Here‚Äôs the key insight üîë

Stablecoins walked so RWAs could run.

Once dollars moved on-chain reliably,
Treasuries, credit, funds, and real assets followed naturally.

Same rails.
Bigger value.
Stablecoin market size check üíµüëá

‚Ä¢ Billions settled daily, not monthly

This is the largest on-chain financial primitive ever built. 
The real stat people miss üëÄ

Stablecoins now settle trillions in annual volume, rivalling major payment networks.

Not speculation.
Not leverage.
Just programmable dollars moving at internet speed.
And institutions noticed.

‚Ä¢ Banks using stablecoins for 24/7 settlement
‚Ä¢ Funds using them as on-chain cash legs
‚Ä¢ RWAs priced, settled, and redeemed in stablecoins

Stablecoins became the base layer of on-chain finance.
Larry Fink's @BlackRock didn‚Äôt ‚Äúexperiment‚Äù with RWAs in 2025.
They scaled them.

Their BUIDL fund crossed $1B+ in tokenised U.S. Treasuries, becoming the largest product of its kind on-chain.

This is what institutional conviction looks like. 
One of the most under-appreciated RWA moves of 2025 üëÄ

Franklin Templeton‚Äôs @FTI_US BENJI tokenised MMF reached ~$700M on-chain, while the firm actively expands tokenisation across its traditional fund lineup.

This is how incumbents adapt. 
Ondo Finance didn‚Äôt just talk about Treasuries.

They tokenised them on-chain with products like OUSG & USDY, giving crypto-native users 24/7 access to U.S. Treasury yield and composability in DeFi.

@OndoFinance 
$50M was deployed into the Anemoy Tokenized Apollo Diversified Credit Fund (ACRDX), launched with @Centrifuge + @plumenetwork, bringing Apollo‚Äôs global private credit strategy on-chain for the first time.

This isn‚Äôt crypto chasing yield.
It‚Äôs institutional credit, compliant and at scale, moving on-chain.
Jamie Diamond's @jpmorgan moved RWAs from theory to scale, processing hundreds of billions in tokenised collateral + launched a money market on Eth.

@GoldmanSachs + @BNYglobal didnt want to get left out so also a tokenized launched a money market.

Institutional private credit moved on-chain at real scale as diversified global credit strategies were tokenised by @ApolloGlobal.
Traditional asset managers pushed beyond custody as tokenised funds and on-chain settlement were explored by @Fidelity.

Compliant issuance took shape as tokenised bonds and funds were piloted across public and permissioned chains by @UBS.

Asia‚Äôs RWA momentum accelerated as tokenised bonds and structured products were integrated into regulated banking operations by @DBSBank.
Washington flipped the switch in 2025.

With executive action on digital assets, the GENIUS Act clarifying stablecoins & RWAs, and a clear pullback from regulation-by-enforcement, the US finally set usable rules.

Clear frameworks unlocked institutional floodgates.
@WhiteHouse 
Jan 1, 2025: pilots, proofs-of-concept, cautious experimentation.

Dec 31, 2025: $30B+ in on-chain RWAs, global banks deployed, asset managers live, regulators aligned.

RWA didn‚Äôt win mindshare.
It became infrastructure.
The biggest shift wasn‚Äôt the numbers.
It was who showed up.

When BlackRock, JPM, Apollo, Fidelity, UBS, DBS and others commit capital, RWAs stop being optional.

This is capital markets choosing new rails. 
In the web3 world Base aligns closest to what we are doing at IXS

One unlocks culture.
The other unlocks capital.

One builds for the next billion users.
The other builds for the next trillion in assets.

One brings people on-chain.
The other brings institutions on-chain.

What matters isn‚Äôt the hype. It‚Äôs the rails: cheap settlement, massive onboarding funnels, and a dev base shipping 1M+ verified contracts on @base @jessepollak

RWAs, payments, and on-chain financial infrastructure only scale where distribution, compliance, and execution actually work.
And founder @brian_armstrong knows exactly what way the wind is blowing in regards to 2026.

"The tokenization of every asset!" 
That‚Äôs why 2026 isn‚Äôt a question of if.
It‚Äôs how fast.

Near-term projections push $50B+ in RWAs, with credible paths toward trillions by 2030 as issuance, settlement, and liquidity fully move on-chain.
2025 proved RWAs work.
2026 is about who can run them at scale.

Bitcoin is the largest asset on-chain.
Yield on Bitcoin remains the hardest problem.

We at IXS deliver institutional Bitcoin yield designed for large capital. 
Most RWA platforms solve one piece of the puzzle.

IXS covers the full lifecycle:
issuance ‚Üí compliance ‚Üí settlement ‚Üí liquidity.

That‚Äôs the difference between experimentation and production markets. 
2026 is coming.
RWAs are just getting started.

If you‚Äôre as excited as we are, retweet the first tweet and spread RWA and IXS

Ethereum $ETH  researchers are raising concerns about state growth and how it could affect decentralization over time.  As more data accumulates on the network, running a full Ethereum node becomes more expensive and resource-heavy. This could limit participation to larger players, reducing decentralization.  To address this, researchers are exploring ideas like state expiry, separating frequently used data from old data, and making nodes less dependent on storing everything.  These are long-term research efforts, but the goal is clear: scale Ethereum without sacrificing decentralization. Ôªø#Ethereum  #Altcoin Season#

üî• Why Vitalik Says Ethereum Still Isn‚Äôt Fully ‚ÄúTrustless‚Äù  Ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin made an uncomfortable admission: despite all its progress,  $ETH  is still not fully trustless. The problem isn‚Äôt open-source code or validators - it‚Äôs that only a small group of experts can truly understand how the protocol works. When that happens, trust shifts from code to people.  As Ethereum keeps adding upgrades, layers, and abstractions, complexity becomes a silent risk. Users and developers end up relying on a handful of highly technical contributors, which slowly weakens decentralization. This is why many still point to $BTC  as a simpler system that‚Äôs easier to independently verify.  The takeaway: Vitalik believes Ethereum should prioritize simplicity over features. Fewer moving parts mean more people can verify the system themselves - and that‚Äôs where real trustlessness comes from.  #BTC Price Analysis#  #ETH#   #Bitcoin Price Prediction: What is Bitcoins next move?#

"Managing trades on the higher timeframes."    This post is in line with the recent Platinum trade that I took on Monday against the weekly high-test candle on $ETH .     The trade went smooth until yesterday when US CPI data forced it to reverse direction that eroded some of the ongoing profits. Some of you have questions around managing this trade. Here's a blueprint of how its done.    If the trade is taken on the higher timeframe i.e weekly or monthly (Long or Short). By default, it should be managed on the same timeframe until it start yielding sizeable profit then we move it to lower timeframes to extract max. output.    But as a smart trader, we should move a step lower on the immediate timeframe to analyze and manage the trade i.e. if the trade was taken on the weekly chart, we should be looking at the daily candles for the possibility of trend reversal.    As per the Ethereum setup, if we have managed the trade on the daily timeframe after placing the trade on weekly, we should have been stopped out on day 3 of placing the trade with minor profit (with trail stop loss). But since, the trade hasn't yet entered a sizeable profit, we're still going as per plan and managing the trade on the weekly chart, resulting in no movement of Stop Loss until next week when I will lower the stop loss just above the last week's high.    A smarter way of managing trade without emotions!

Question of the Day? 

Question: 
So sorry to ask, how does Amara marry with $Dione

Answer:
‚ÄúFirst, Amara is deployed natively on the Odyssey chain. That means every single action on Amara happens on Odyssey itself. Swapping tokens, listing new pairs, adding liquidity, removing liquidity, claiming rewards; all of these actions trigger real on-chain transactions on Odyssey. This isn‚Äôt an external app or an off-chain system. It‚Äôs fully built into the chain.

Because of that, the gas fee for all Amara activity is paid in DIONE. So anyone who wants to interact with Amara, whether they‚Äôre coming from Base, Ethereum, or any other ecosystem, has to acquire DIONE to pay for gas. There‚Äôs no way around that. As Amara usage grows, gas usage grows, and that creates consistent, organic demand for DIONE tied directly to real activity.

On top of that, Amara is designed to attract users and liquidity from outside ecosystems. As those users bridge assets in and start trading or providing liquidity, they are automatically pulled into the Dione economy. They are no longer just external users, they now need DIONE to operate on Odyssey. This is one of the strongest ways to convert external attention into real ecosystem participation.

Then there‚Äôs the TVL side of things. Amara introduces spot liquidity, LP positions, bonded liquidity, and longer-term locked capital. All of this contributes directly to the total value locked on the Odyssey chain. Higher TVL improves the overall strength, visibility, and credibility of the ecosystem, which benefits every project building on it, not just Amara.

As the perps infrastructure rolls out, there‚Äôs another layer of value. Certain pool configurations and risk structures require DIONE to be present in protocol-controlled pools. In those cases, the Amara team itself needs to acquire DIONE as part of the system design. That means real protocol-level demand, not speculative buying.

There‚Äôs also the possibility, not confirmed yet, but very realistic, that some trading pairs or routing paths involve DIONE directly. If and when that happens, it introduces even more swap volume, LP activity, and utility around the DIONE token. But even without this, DIONE already benefits significantly from gas usage and infrastructure demand alone.

When you combine all of this, native deployment on Odyssey, gas fees paid in DIONE, external users being forced to acquire DIONE, rising TVL on the chain, protocol-level demand from perps, and potential future DIONE-based pools, you start to see the bigger picture.‚Äù - @god_xte
